div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Bristol merchant John King, September 12, 1728, to order powder, shot, and bar iron.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John King, September 12, 1728

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr. the 12th: 1728
John King Esqr.

div1.p:
This is a Short line to desire you will take
the first opportunity to Send me in two hundred weight of your
Bristol Shott and fifty weight of good Powder and if you Send me
in five hundred weight of Flatt and Square Barrs of Iron it will not
be unwelcome I am I am [sic]Sir—
Yor. humble Servt.

closer.seg:
Sir, Yor. humble Servt.
per Raymond

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1728 August-1731 July, Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.
[1] No information about Captain Raymond has been found.
